channel.title: Galleries on Homicide in Chicago 1870-1930
channel.description: Recent content in Galleries on Homicide in Chicago 1870-1930

item.title: Cynthia Bowman
item.description: Cynthia Bowman is author of “Wife Murder in Chicago” At the time of this recording she was Professor of Law, Northwestern University School of Law.

item.title: David Tannenhaus
item.description: Prof. David Tannenhaus speaks about the juvenile justice system in Chicago.

item.title: David Van Zandt
item.description: Interview with David Van Zandt. At the time of this recording he was the Dean of the School of Law, Northwestern University.

item.title: Dawn Clark-Netsch
item.description: Dawn Clark-Netsch, Professor of Law Emerita, Northwestern University School of Law, talks about her life.

item.title: Dominick Pacyga
item.description: Interview with Dominic Pacyga about the history of Chicago and patterns of immigration to the city during the period 1870-1930. At the time of this recording he was Professor of History, Columbia College.

item.title: Harold Shapiro
item.description: Victor Rosenblum, Professor of Law Emeritus, Northwestern Uinersity, talks about his life.

item.title: Howard Trienens
item.description: Howard Trienens, partner at Sibley Austin, talks about his career as a practicing lawyer.

item.title: Judges Pincham and Strayhorn
item.description: Judges R. Eugene Pincham and Earl E. Strayhorn discuss capital punishment, judicial elections, corruption, legal education and the Scottsboro Case.

item.title: Larry Marshall
item.description: Prof. Larry Marshall, whose practice focuses in the area of death penalty litigation and avocacy on behalf of the wrongly convicted, speaks about the death penalty and the former Governor’s decision to halt its use in Illinois.

item.title: Leigh Bienen
item.description: Project Director, Leigh B. Bienen, provides an overview of the website’s inception, intent and design. At the time of this recording she was Senior Lecturer, Northwestern University School of Law.

item.title: Michael Lesy
item.description: Michael Lesy talks about his upcoming book “Murder City”. At the time of this recording he was Professor of Literary Journalism, Hampshire College, Amherst, MA.

item.title: Michelle Oberman
item.description: Michelle Oberman talks about her study of infanticide from the Chicago Historical Homicide dataset. At the time of this recording she was Professor of Law, Santa Clara University School of Law.

item.title: Richard Brooks
item.description: Richard Brooks is author of “Life Terms or Death Sentences: The Uneasy Relationship Between Judicial Elections and Capital Punishment.” At the time of this recording he was Assistant Professor of Law, Yale Law School.

item.title: Scott Turow
item.description: Scott Turow, Chicago writer and lawyer, talks about his life.

item.title: Steven Drizin
item.description: Steven A. Drizin talks about his article in the JCLC on juvenile crime and courts in Chicago. At the time of this recording he was Clinical Professor of Law, Northwestern University School of Law.

item.title: Thomas Geraghty
item.description: Professor Geraghty discusses the 1929 People vs Fisher case, and the Cook County juvenile court system. At the time of this recording he was Associate Dean for Clinical Education and Director, Bluhm Legal Clinic.

item.title: Victor Rosenblum
item.description: Victor Rosenblum, Professor of Law Emeritus, Northwestern Uinersity, talks about his life.
